title: Ball-terminal slab serif with personality
content:
Born anew in a certain coffee retailer’s campaign for young hearts and minds

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20080907002644im_/http:/www.typophile.com/files/IMG_0871_6233.JPG)

 [‹ Approximation of child's handwriting](http://web.archive.org/web/20080907002644/http:/www.typophile.com/node/43030 "Go to previous forum topic") [Help with identifying bitmapped script font ›](http://web.archive.org/web/20080907002644/http:/www.typophile.com/node/43019 "Go to next forum topic")
author: roquestrew

comments.content:
also saw this at the airport yesterday and snapped a quick picture. :)

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20080907002644im_/http:/www.typophile.com/files/coffee_4941.jpg)

upon closer inspection, the letters appeared imperfect, suggesting it was lettered on paper and digitized, without too much worry about clean glyphs, or too much thought as to how the spacing should work. ;)

it’s definitely eye catching.

Also on the Starbucks type front:

[Typeguy](http://web.archive.org/web/20080907002644/http:/www.typeguy.com/) did a nice Bodoni

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20080907002644im_/http:/www.typophile.com/files/bruceslab_5724.jpg)

Its quirky in the same way Storm’s Farao is.

Mikey :-)

It called to mind Farao for me, too; and I know what you mean about the imperfections

Does anyone remember the “Skinny Latte” marketing material/signage? They had a nice serif they were using, but I was digital camera-less at the time.
